did.unittitle: Paul D. Boyer papers
did.abstract: Paul D. Boyer won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1997 for his research on the binding change mechanism and rotational catalysis of the ATP synthase complex, which he performed at UCLA in the 1960-70s. This collection contains his professional papers, documenting his career as an academic at the University of Minnesota (1946-1963) and UCLA (1963-present [Emeritus]), where he was Director of the Molecular Biology Institute (MBI). Of particular note is Boyer's correspondence with other major bioenergeticists of the twentieth century including Efraim Racker and Nobelist Peter Mitchell, and regarding UCLA specifically, the naming of UCLA's Boyer Hall on campus.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Jessica Cook and Joyce Wang in the Center for Primary Research and Training (CFPRT) under the direction of Jillian Cuellar and Courtney Dean, Summer-Fall 2016.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

bioghist.head: Biography/History
bioghist.p: Paul D. Boyer (1918–present) was born on July 31st, 1918 in Provo, Utah. He graduated from Brigham Young University with a B.S. in chemistry in 1939, was awarded a Wisconsin Alumni Research Foundation Scholarship, and began his doctoral work at the University of Wisconsin in 1939 in the lab of Paul H. Philips. Five days before leaving Provo, Boyer married fellow BYU student Lyda Whicker. He received his PhD in biochemistry from the University of Wisconsin in 1943, and moved to Stanford to work in the lab of J. Murray Luck on a war-related research project on the stabilization of serum albumin for transfusions. In 1945 Boyer was drafted into the U.S. Navy (second class seaman) and sent to the Navy Medical Research Institute. In 1946 he became an Assistant Professor at University of Minnesota. In 1955 Boyer received a Guggenheim Fellowship to work with Nobelist Hugo Theorell on alcohol dehydrogenase in Sweden, and also won the Award in Enzyme Chemistry from the American Chemical Society (ACS) that year. In 1956 Boyer accepted the Hill Foundation Professorship at the University of Minnesota and moved to the medical campus. He served as Chairman of the Biochemistry Section of the American Chemical Society from 1959-60.

In 1963 Boyer moved to UCLA, and in 1965 accepted the more administrative Directorship of the new Molecular Biology Institute (MBI). From 1969-70 Boyer also served as President of the American Society of Biological Chemists. In late 1970 Boyer's lab made a breakthrough discovery, formulating the first major aspect of what, along with his later theory of catalytic cooperativity (developed in the mid-1970s), became the binding change mechanism. He was eventually awarded the 1997 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for this research, after John Walker's crystallographic studies confirmed Boyer's formulation (Boyer, Walker, and Jens Skou shared the 1997 Prize).

From 1963-89 Boyer served as either Editor or Associate Editor of the Annual Review of Biochemistry, and from 1970-90 he was the Editor of the multivolume biochemistry series The Enzymes. In addition to his Nobel Prize he received numerous awards, including the Rose Award of the American Society of Chemistry and Molecular Biology (1989) and honorary doctorates from the Universities of Stockholm (1974), Minnesota (1996), and Wisconsin (1998). He is a Member of the National Academy of Sciences. Boyer's lab largely stopped preforming research around 1993, and after which he spent an increasing amount of his time in Wyoming with his wife, Lyda. They have three children (Gail, Hali, and Douglas) and eight grandchildren.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection contains materials largely related to Paul Boyer's professional career, most significantly research notes, article manuscripts, conference attendance, and correspondence related to his Nobel Prize-winning research on the binding change mechanism and rotational catalysis in the ATP synthase complex. This collection is especially strong in correspondence, containing Boyer's extensive research correspondence with Nobelist Peter Mitchell, bioenergeticist Efraim Racker, Richard Cross, Britton Chance, Henry Lardy, and James Peter. The collection also contains extensive article manuscripts with data, notes, and revisions. Lastly, the collection contains UCLA-specific materials such as documentation of the beginnings of the MBI, the naming of Boyer Hall, and the creation of the Boyer Postdoctoral fund.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Overall, materials are arranged alphabetically by topic within their series, then chronologically.

This collection has been arranged into the following series:
Series 1: Academia, 1941-2008
Subseries 1.1: Teaching, Academic Appointments, Personal Information, 1941-1999
Subseries 1.2: Publications, 1949-2007
Subseries 1.3: Conferences, 1967-2005
Subseries 1.4: Professional Societies, 1955-2008
Subseries 1.5: UCLA, 1974-2009
Series 2: Correspondence, 1943-2009
Series 3: Awards and Donations, 1951-2009
Series 4: Government Funding and Contracts, 1955-1995

did.unittitle: Series 1: Academia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series (1941-2008) includes material related to Boyer's occupation as a professor, including article and book chapter manuscripts; conference lectures, notes, and programs; UCLA graduate seminar lecture notes; research notes and data; employment paperwork from University of Minnesota and UCLA; professional societies and editorial materials; and photographs of him and his colleagues. This series also contains correspondence and co-authored drafts/notes relating to specific articles or chapters. In terms of UCLA material, the series documents Boyer's Directorship of the Molecular Biology Institute (MBI) at UCLA, the UC Program for Research and Training in Biotechnology (also called the Systemwide Biotechnology Research and Education Program), his involvement with other UCLA campus institutes, the proceedings of UCLA advisory committees he served on, and information regarding the proposed Veloway bicycle highway project near UCLA's campus in Westwood. For material related to the naming of Boyer Hall, the creation of the Paul Boyer Endowed Chair at UCLA, and the Boyer Postdoctoral Fellowships at UCLA, see series 3.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are sorted by document type (academic appointment, article, conference, etc.) within the subseries.

Subseries 1.2: Publications

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains Boyer's numerous authored/co-authored articles and book chapters. Frequent co-authors include Michael Gresser, Vladimir Kasho, Yakov M. Milgrom, Marat Murataliev, and Teri Melese. Subseries also contains a number of publications by Peter Mitchell and miscellaneously authored titles, as well as folders including loose prints, transparencies, and negatives of Boyer's article figures, tables, and charts.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged by first author as it appears on the published version, then chronologically.

Subseries 1.3: Conferences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains materials related to the numerous meetings and lectures that Paul Boyer attended from the 1960s to the 1990s. Most of the records pertain to research symposiums held by universities in the US as well as countries abroad such as Italy, Israel, South Africa, the Netherlands, and Thailand, to name a few. Conferences held by scientific societies such as the American Chemical Society (ACS), the American Society of Biological Chemists (ASBC, later the American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology or ASBMB), the European Bioenergetics Conference (EBEC), and the Federation of European Biochemical Societies (FEBS) comprise the rest of the materials. Professor Boyer cites the Gordon Research Conferences (GRC) as having been particularly meaningful to him throughout his career. The GRC folders often contain group photos of conference attendees, comprising the majority of the collection's sparse photographic content. Some folders contain minimal information such as plane tickets and confirmation of attendance, although others have notes that Boyer took at those conferences as well as related correspondence.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Items are positioned (with a few exceptions) within boxes chronologically by the date of the conference and then alphabetically by conference title or venue.

did.unittitle: Subseries 1.4: Professional Societies

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains information relating to Boyer's leadership and membership positions in the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, American Chemical Society (ACS), American Society of Biological Chemists (ASBC), as well as the National Academy of Science (NAS). It also contains correspondence about his editorial work on the 18-volume treatise The Enzymes and with the "Recollections" section of Protein Science.

Subseries 1.5: UCLA

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This subseries has material related to Boyer's involvement in various UCLA projects, ranging from a proposed bikeway (the WestLA Veloway) to the creation and leadership of the Molecular Biology Institute (MBI). 2 folders pertaining to the attempted establishment of UC-affiliated companies that would profit off of university research are also available, as are folders containing materials about joint research projects between UCLA and the US Department of Energy such as the Laboratory of Structural Biology and Molecular Medicine (LSBMM).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains a retrospective note from Boyer about his opposition to a proposal by UC Vice President Ronald W. Brady for the establishment of UC-affiliated technology transfer companies. The plan called for the establishment of the non-profit UC Technology Development Foundation (UCTDF) and the for-profit UC Technology Development Company, the latter with the stated intention of bolstering funds for biotechnology research. The proposal was met with heavy resistance from a number of faculty who were concerned that the plan would undermine the ethos of scientific progress and was ultimately turned down.

Series 2: Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains Boyer's general and research correspondence, which is virtually all professional in subject matter. Of major interest is correspondence delineating Boyer's research journey from his discoveries at the University of Minnesota, where he first began researching oxidative phosphorylation, to his eventual breakthrough on the binding change mechanism and rotational catalysis at UCLA in the 1970s. Correspondents Henry Lardy, David Green, Richard Cross, Nobelist Peter Mitchell, Richard Cross, Britton Chance, Efraim Racker, Kathryn LaNoue, and James Peter figure prominently in this series. For drafts with accompanying correspondence about specific articles, also see series 1.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series keeps the distinction between "correspondence" and "research correspondence" from Boyer's original filing system; however, researchers should note that there are not tangible thematic differences between "research correspondence" and general "correspondence," as virtually all is research-related. Frequent correspondents with Boyer have their own folders titled under their name and are arranged alphabetically. Less frequent correspondents were filed under "miscellaneous authors" and categorized by year. Series of correspondence concerning particular topics were kept in their original arrangement and filed under "miscellaneous authors".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains 2008 note from Boyer delineating the origins of some of the materials in this subseries, particularly for letters dating from the 1960s to 1980s with Peter Mitchell. Note explains that the original copies had been borrowed by Bruce Weber, who sent back the scans he made of the originals in 2006 at Boyer's request. However, during the processing period, many originals were found anyways despite claims of having "mysteriously disappeared", and a significant portion of these scans were removed from the collection.

Series 3: Awards & Donations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains material related to awards (including competitive funding from non-academic private institutions like the Guggenheim Foundation, and lectureships that function as awards like the Weizmann Lecture Series), and donations. Of particular interest are lectures, interviews, and correspondence relating to Boyer's 1997 Nobel Prize in Chemistry (also see series 2), as well as material relating to Boyer's 1955 Guggenheim Fellowship, 1989 Rose Award, and 1998 Seaborg Medal. The series also contains material documenting his nominating of other scholars for these awards. In addition, it contains material relating to Boyer's donating of his Nobel Prize monies to create the Boyer Postdoctoral Fellowships at UCLA, University of Minnesota, and the University of Wisconsin, as well as material relating to the creation of the Paul Boyer Endowed Chair at UCLA and the naming of Boyer Hall on UCLA's campus in large part through contributions by James Peter (a former postdoc of Boyer's) and the Albert Parvin Foundation. For other UCLA-related material, see series 1 and 2.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials pertaining to "Awards" and "Nominations" are arranged in alphabetical order by name of the award. "Donations" and "Honorary Events" are sorted chronologically.

did.unittitle: Series 4: Government Funding and Contracts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains material related to Boyer's government funding research grants, including those from the Atomic Energy Commission (AEC), Department of Energy (DOE), Energy Research and Development Administration (ERDA), National Science Foundation (NSF), and the United States Public Health Service (USPHS).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials in this series are arranged alphabetically, first by government organization (AEC, DOE, etc.), and then chronologically based on the requested grant period. The sponsored project titles are included in the labels of some of the folder; those without are a renewal of the previous project grant.
